{{Infobox Organization |name = Turkish Cycling Federation
Türkiye Bisiklet Federasyonu |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = TBF |motto = |formation = 1923 |type = [[Public ownership|Government organisation]] |status = |purpose = Sport |headquarters = [[Ulus, Ankara|Ulus]] |location = [[Ankara]], Turkey |region_served = Turkey |language = [[Turkish language|Turkish]] |leader_title = President |leader_name = [[Erol Küçükbakırcı]] |parent_organization = GSGM |website = {{URL|http://bisiklet.gov.tr/}} |remarks = }} The '''Turkish Cycling Federation''' ({{lang-tr|Türkiye Bisiklet Federasyonu}}, TBF) is the national [[sport governing body|governing body]] of [[bicycle racing|cycle racing]] in [[Turkey]]. Founded in 1923, its headquarters is located in [[Ulus, Ankara|Ulus]] quarter of [[Ankara]]. Current president of TBF is Emin Müftüoğlu. The TBF is a member of the [[Union Cycliste Internationale|UCI]] and the [[Union Européenne de Cyclisme|UEC]]. ==History== The first bicycle competition held in Turkish history was organized by ethnic [[Armenians|Armenian]] Leon effendi and Papazyan in 1910-1912 in the city of [[Salonica]].{{cite web|title=History of our Federation|url=http://bisiklet.gov.tr/tr/bilgi/Tarih%C3%A7e/1/1/Federasyonumuzun%20Tarihi|publisher=Turkish Cycling Federation|accessdate=5 February 2013|language=Turkish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130430102140/http://www.bisiklet.gov.tr/tr/bilgi/Tarih%C3%A7e/1/1/Federasyonumuzun%20Tarihi|archivedate=30 April 2013|df=}} Eventually, these Cycling competitions got sponsored by the [[Fenerbahçe S.K.|Fenerbahçe]] sports club which organized races from the Fenerbahçe neighborhood, then [[Maslak]], and [[Bakirkoy]]. The '''Turkish Cycling Federation''' was eventually established in 1923. Its first national competition was held in 1927 which started from [[Taksim Stadium|Taksim]] and ended in [[Bulgaria]]. ==Events== The federation organizes following cycling events every year, which are part of [[UCI Europe Tour]] and are rated with 2.2: * [[Presidential Cycling Tour of Turkey]] * [[Tour of Alanya]] in [[Alanya]], [[Antalya Province]] (since 2010) * [[Tour of Cappadocia]] in [[Cappadocia]], [[Nevşehir Province]] (since 2011) * [[Tour of Gallipoli]] in [[Gallipoli]], [[Çanakkale Province]] * [[Tour of Isparta]] in [[Isparta]] (since 2011) * [[Tour of Marmara]] in [[Marmara Region]] (since 2010) * [[Mersin Road Cycling Race]] in [[Mersin]] (since 2012) * [[Tour of Trakya]] in [[Tekirdağ]], [[East Thrace]] (since 2010) * [[Tour of Victory]], western Turkey as well as * [[Turkish National Road Race Championships]] * [[Turkish National Time Trial Championships]] Other events are:{{cite web |url=http://bisiklet.gov.tr/tr/detay/bisikletin-dag-ve-yolu-alanyada-bulusuyor/322 |publisher=Türkiye Bisiklet Federasyonu |title=Bisikletin Dağ ve Yolu Alanya'da Buluşuyor |date=2012-11-02 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2012-07-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120805174538/http://bisiklet.gov.tr/tr/detay/bisikletin-dag-ve-yolu-alanyada-bulusuyor/322 |archivedate=2012-08-05 |df= }} * [[Adana MTB Cup]] * Tour of Mevlana * Tour of Sivas * Tour of Trabzon. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081006170238/http://www.bisikletfederasyonu.gov.tr/ Turkish Cycling Federation official website] {{Sports governing bodies in Turkey}} {{National Members of the Union Cycliste Internationale}} {{International cycling}} [[Category:National members of the European Cycling Union]] [[Category:Cycle racing organisations]] [[Category:Sports governing bodies in Turkey|Cycling]] [[Category:Sports organisations established in 1923]] [[Category:Organizations based in Ankara]] [[Category:Cycle racing in Turkey|Federation]] [[Category:1923 establishments in Turkey]] {{cycling-org-stub}} {{turkey-sport-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox sportsperson | name = Zdeněk Koubek | image = Zdenka Koubkova 1936.jpg | image_size = | caption = Zdeněk Koubek in 1936 | birth_name = | fullname = | nationality = | residence = | birth_date = 8 December 1913 | birth_place = [[Paskov]], [[Moravia]], [[Austria-Hungary]] | death_date = 12 June 1986 | death_place = [[Prague]], [[Czechoslovakia]] | height = | weight = | country = | sport = Running, high jump, long jump | club = VS Brno
VS Praha | retired = | olympics = | highestranking = | show-medals = | medaltemplates = {{MedalCountry|{{TCH}}}} {{MedalCompetition|[[Women's World Games]]}} {{MedalGold|[[1934 Women's World Games|1934 London]]|800 m}} {{MedalBronze|[[1934 Women's World Games|1934 London]]|Long jump}} }} '''Zdeněk Koubek''' (born '''Zdena "Zdeňka" Koubková''', 8 December 1913 – 12 June 1986) was a track athlete from [[Czechoslovakia]]. He won two medals at the [[1934 Women's World Games]] and several national titles in the 100–800 m running, long jump and high jump, and set a few world records in running events. In 1936, he underwent female to male gender reassignment surgery and retired from athletics. ==Biography== Koubek was born in Paskov, in a family of eight siblings. Soon after his birth, the family moved to [[Brno]], where he finished school and started training in athletics. Koubková continued his education and training in Prague. In 1934 he won five national titles, in the 100 m, 200 m and 800 m running, high jump and long jump. On 14 June 1934 he set his first world record, in the 800 m at 2:16.4. His next world record came in the medley relay (2×100 m, 200 m and 800 m), at 3:14.4. Later in August, Koubek won the 800 m event at the [[1934 Women's World Games]], in a world record time of 2:12.4, and finished third in the long jump with a national record of 5.70 m. Around that time newspapers started discussing his excessive (for a woman) masculinity, noting that pants would suit him better than a skirt. In 1935 Koubek retired from competitions and for six months toured the United States. The next year, he underwent gender reassignment surgery and changed his name. He abandoned athletics and a potential coaching career, and only after World War II did he join the team of his brother Jaroslav and played rugby for a local club. Koubek spent his late years living with a wife in Prague, where he died aged 73. A 1935 novel ''Zdenin světový rekord'' (''Zdena's world record'') by Lída Merlínová is based on his early life and career. ==References== {{Commons category|Zdenka Koubkova}} {{Reflist|refs= {{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/j.endeavour.2010.09.005| pmid = 20980057| title = Testing sex and gender in sports; reinventing, reimagining and reconstructing histories| journal = Endeavour| volume = 34| issue = 4| pages = 157–63| year = 2010| last1 = Heggie | first1 = V. | pmc = 3007680}} [http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,756527,00.html Medicine: Change of Sex]. ''Time''. 24 August 1936 [http://encyklopedie.brna.cz/home-mmb/?acc=profil_osobnosti&load=11754 Zdena/Zdeněk Koubková/Koubek]. encyklopedie.brna.cz [http://www.translide.cz/zdenek-koubek Zdeněk Koubek]. translide.cz }} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Koubkova, Zdena}} [[Category:1913 births]] [[Category:1986 deaths]] [[Category:Czech female middle-distance runners]] [[Category:Czech long jumpers]] [[Category:Transgender and transsexual men]] [[Category:Transgender and transsexual sportspeople]] [[Category:Gender verification in sports]] [[Category:LGBT people from Czechoslovakia]]
